DOCNAME: ASSOCIATION OF THE VICTIMS OF TERRORISM v. SPAIN
TEXT: The applicant is a GPE association that was formed in DATE to protect the interests of victims and relatives of victims of acts of terrorism . It was represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON and Mr NORP , lawyers practising in GPE .
judgment of DATE to which reference is made below , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE the terrorist organisation ORG released a communiqué entitled “ NORP alternative ” ( ORG ) through a newspaper , Egin .

A decision was taken by ORG ( GPE ) , the executive body of the political movement , PERSON , to take active steps to disseminate the communiqué from DATE . The decision was taken by a differently composed GPE from that which was subsequently prosecuted .

In DATE the newly composed ORG drafted a document entitled “ Presentation of the democratic alternative to the people ” ( Presentación Popular de la Alternativa Democrática ) , in which it set out a strategy for disseminating pro - ORG propaganda through advertisements placed in the press , in particular with the PERSON newspaper , and through other channels of communication with the general public in ORG .

At DATE , shortly before the general election on DATE , unidentified members of ORG sent the ORG CARDINAL videocassettes on “ Alternativa Democrática ” . During a meeting on CARDINAL DATE and in accordance with ORG , DATE and CARDINAL of its articles of association which defined it as the executive body of ORG party with responsibility for representing the political movement , the ORG agreed to adopt the content of the cassettes and to arrange for their dissemination , and also to allow ORG to use advertising slots that , as a legally recognised political party , had been reserved to ORG free of charge for its party political broadcasts . The cassettes presented ORG ’s “ Alternativa Democrática ” programme , with its logo , symbols and weapons , and called , inter alia , for the independence and self - determination of the NORP people , an unconditional general amnesty and the withdrawal of ORG from the territory claimed .
On DATE the public prosecutor lodged a complaint with central investigating judge no . CARDINAL , who started an investigation ( diligencias previas ) .

On DATE the central investigating judge issued an injunction prohibiting the dissemination of the material in slots reserved for free party political broadcasts and of radio announcements intended for that purpose .
By a decision of DATE , the central investigating judge agreed to permit the applicant to join the proceedings against the CARDINAL members of the GPE concerned as a third - party prosecutor .

On DATE ORG held that it had jurisdiction to hear the case , which had been assigned to it as some of those allegedly involved in the matters complained of were members of the parliaments of the autonomous communities of ORG and GPE .

On DATE the public prosecutor lodged his submissions . The applicant did likewise on CARDINAL DATE . It argued that the GPE acts should be classified as the offence of membership of an armed and the continuing offence of aiding and abetting an armed organisation or , in the alternative , of aiding and abetting an armed organisation and the continuing offence of vindication of offences under ORG CARDINAL bis ( b ) and CARDINAL bis ( a ) § CARDINAL of LAW , or the continuing offence of vindication of terrorism , contrary to LAW . The ORG lodged its defence submissions on DATE .

By a judgment of ORG on DATE , the members of the ORG were acquitted of the offences of being members of an armed organisation and of vindicating acts of terrorism , but convicted under LAW ( a ) of LAW of aiding and abetting an armed organisation . They were sentenced to DATE imprisonment .

The ORG lodged an amparo appeal with the Constitutional Court based on their rights to a fair trial and to have their case heard by an independent and impartial court established by law , their right not to incriminate themselves , their rights to respect for freedom of expression and information , to respect for freedom of thought and to take part in politics , and lastly the presumption of innocence and the principle of equality .
On DATE the public prosecutor lodged his pleading setting out his reasons for contesting the grounds relied on by those seeking amparo relief . The applicant followed suit on DATE .

By a judgment of DATE , which was served on the applicant on DATE , ORG , sitting as a full court composed of CARDINAL judges , granted the PERSON amparo relief and quashed the judgment appealed against . It held that the ORG ’s right protected by the rule requiring that offences and punishments shall be strictly defined by law had been infringed by the application of LAW and QUANTITY of LAW , in that the penalty imposed was disproportionate on the facts of the case . CARDINAL dissenting opinions and CARDINAL concurring opinions were annexed to the judgment .

“ ORG may at any time before adopting its decision inform the parties that other grounds exist , apart from those that have been relied on , that are of relevance to admissibility and , if applicable , to the merits . In such cases a single hearing shall be held for the parties within DATE and the period for delivery of the decision shall be extended accordingly . ”

In NORP law the right to bring a criminal prosecution is public . In addition to the public prosecutor , private citizens are entitled to institute criminal proceedings . ORG may bring a private prosecution ( for offences that may be prosecuted by the injured party ) ; these take the form of a special prosecution or a third - party prosecution , the latter being for offences for which a prosecution lies ex officio ( LAW , section CARDINAL of LAW on PERSON and LAW ) . By Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW , third - party prosecutions , unlike special prosecutions , are commenced by a criminal complaint ( querella ) lodged by someone other than the victim of the crime .
